notes.text:
An update for the httpd:2.4 module is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The httpd packages provide the Apache HTTP Server, a powerful, efficient, and extensible web server.

The following packages have been upgraded to a later upstream version: mod_http2 (1.15.7). (BZ#1814236)

Security Fix(es):

* httpd: memory corruption on early pushes (CVE-2019-10081)

* httpd: read-after-free in h2 connection shutdown (CVE-2019-10082)

* httpd: null-pointer dereference in mod_remoteip (CVE-2019-10097)

* httpd: mod_rewrite configurations vulnerable to open redirect (CVE-2020-1927)

* httpd: mod_http2: DoS via slow, unneeded request bodies (CVE-2018-17189)

* httpd: mod_http2: read-after-free on a string compare (CVE-2019-0196)

* httpd: mod_http2: possible crash on late upgrade (CVE-2019-0197)

* httpd: limited cross-site scripting in mod_proxy error page (CVE-2019-10092)

* httpd: mod_rewrite potential open redirect (CVE-2019-10098)

* httpd: mod_proxy_ftp use of uninitialized value (CVE-2020-1934)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.

Additional Changes:

For detailed information on changes in this release, see the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.3 Release Notes linked from the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: In Apache HTTP server versions 2.4.37 and prior, by sending request bodies in a slow loris way to plain resources, the h2 stream for that request unnecessarily occupied a server thread cleaning up that incoming data. This affects only HTTP/2 (mod_http2) connections.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2018-17189 httpd: mod_http2: DoS via slow, unneeded request bodies
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-17189 httpd: mod_http2: DoS via slow, unneeded request bodies

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in Apache HTTP Server 2.4.17 to 2.4.38. Using fuzzed network input, the http/2 request handling could be made to access freed memory in string comparison when determining the method of a request and thus process the request incorrectly.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2019-0196 httpd: mod_http2: read-after-free on a string compare
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2019-0196 httpd: mod_http2: read-after-free on a string compare

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in Apache HTTP Server 2.4.34 to 2.4.38. When HTTP/2 was enabled for a http: host or H2Upgrade was enabled for h2 on a https: host, an Upgrade request from http/1.1 to http/2 that was not the first request on a connection could lead to a misconfiguration and crash. Server that never enabled the h2 protocol or that only enabled it for https: and did not set "H2Upgrade on" are unaffected by this issue.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2019-0197 httpd: mod_http2: possible crash on late upgrade
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2019-0197 httpd: mod_http2: possible crash on late upgrade

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in Apache httpd, in mod_http2. Under certain circumstances, HTTP/2 early pushes could lead to memory corruption, causing a server to crash.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: memory corruption on early pushes
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

This flaw is only exploitable if Apache httpd is configured to respond to HTTP/2 requests, which is done by including "h2" or "h2c" in the "Protocols" list in a configuration file.  The following command can be used to search for possible vulnerable configurations: 

    grep -R '^\s*Protocols\>.*\<h2\>' /etc/httpd/

See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_http2.html

notes.text: A read-after-free vulnerability was discovered in Apache httpd, in mod_http2. A specially crafted http/2 client session could cause the server to read memory that was previously freed during connection shutdown, potentially leading to a crash.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: read-after-free in h2 connection shutdown
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

This flaw is only exploitable if Apache httpd is configured to respond to HTTP/2 requests, which is done by including "h2" or "h2c" in the "Protocols" list in a configuration file.  The following command can be used to search for possible vulnerable configurations: 

    grep -R '^\s*Protocols\>.*\<h2\>' /etc/httpd/

See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_http2.html

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')

notes.text: A cross-site scripting vulnerability was found in Apache httpd, affecting the mod_proxy error page. Under certain circumstances, a crafted link could inject content into the HTML displayed in the error page, potentially leading to client-side exploitation.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: limited cross-site scripting in mod_proxy error page
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

This flaw is only exploitable if Proxy* directives are used in Apache httpd configuration.  The following command can be used to search for possible vulnerable configurations:

    grep -R '^\s*Proxy' /etc/httpd/

See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_proxy.html

vulnerabilities.title: limited cross-site scripting in mod_proxy error page

notes.text:
A vulnerability was discovered in Apache httpd, in mod_remoteip. A trusted proxy using the "PROXY" protocol could send specially crafted headers that can cause httpd to experience a stack buffer overflow or NULL pointer dereference, leading to a crash or other potential consequences.

This issue could only be exploited by configured trusted intermediate proxy servers. HTTP clients such as browsers could not exploit the vulnerability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: null-pointer dereference in mod_remoteip
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

This flaw is only exploitable if RemoteIP* directives are used in Apache httpd configuration.  The following command can be used to search for possible vulnerable configurations:

    grep -R '^\s*RemoteIP' /etc/httpd/

See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_remoteip.html

notes.text: A vulnerability was discovered in Apache httpd, in mod_rewrite. Certain self-referential mod_rewrite rules could be fooled by encoded newlines, causing them to redirect to an unexpected location. An attacker could abuse this flaw in a phishing attack or as part of a client-side attack on browsers.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: mod_rewrite potential open redirect
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

This flaw requires the use of certain Rewrite configuration directives.  The following command can be used to search for possible vulnerable configurations:

    grep -R '^\s*Rewrite' /etc/httpd/

See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_rewrite.html

cwe.name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

notes.text: A flaw was found in Apache HTTP Server (httpd) versions 2.4.0 to 2.4.41. Redirects configured with mod_rewrite that were intended to be self-referential might be fooled by encoded newlines and redirected instead to an unexpected URL within the request URL.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: mod_rewrite configurations vulnerable to open redirect
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This issue only affects httpd versions between 2.4.0 and 2.4.41. Therefore Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 and 6 are not affected by this flaw.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: mod_rewrite configurations vulnerable to open redirect

notes.text: A flaw was found in Apache's HTTP server (httpd) .The mod_proxy_ftp module may use uninitialized memory with proxying to a malicious FTP server. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: mod_proxy_ftp use of uninitialized value
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This flaw is caused by use of an uninitialized memory variable. Practically this has no impact, but in some corner cases it is possible that the contents of this variable could be read by a remote process, causing loss of confidentiality as a result of this. There is no evidence of code execution.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
